Description: Cypriot terracotta figure of a baboon or bear. Squatting and holding food to its mouth with its left hand and holding its stomach or groin with its right hand. Missing both legs. Bichrome striped decoration in red and black, with red ears, mouth and groin. Dark pink fabric with cream coloured surface and fine white and black inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ16 or 17
Curator's comments: Monkey/ bear figurines appear in the 6th century BC and use through the Cypro-Archaic II period (600-475BC, Karageorghis 1996), occasionally in more recent that 5th century BC contexts (though probably residual). There are similar examples from Cyprus, though it is often difficult to distinguish between reprsentations of bear or monkey (Karageorghis 1996, 19-21). Karageorghis, V. 1996. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus.VI. The Cypro-Archaic Period monsters, animals and miscellanea. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.085) (Phase 1)
